intro: Mocinia, commonly known as the white beech, is a rare and endangered plant species native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Fagaceae family, which includes oaks and chestnuts, and is characterized by its smooth, white bark and oval-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers followed by edible, chestnut-like nuts. Due to habitat loss and limited genetic diversity, conservation efforts are crucial for its survival. Its unique botanical features make it an important species for ecological and botanical study.
